title: JavaScript does not technically support private members as a language feature. Privacy -
described by Douglas Crockford
a
http://javascript.crockford.com/private.html
- gets emulated instead via closures (preserved function scope) that will be generated each with every instantiation call of a constructor function.

inline_content.Text: JavaScript does not technically support private members as a language feature. Privacy -
- gets emulated instead via closures (preserved function scope) that will be generated each with every instantiation call of a constructor function.

Queue
c
example demonstrates how, with constructor functions, local state can be preserved and made accessible too via privileged methods.

title: Making use of this pattern - emulating private members via privileged public methods - one should keep in mind that, with every instance, additional memory will be consumed for every
own property
i
method (for it is code that canâ€™t be shared/reused). The same is true for the amount/size of state that is going to be stored within such a closure.
